column1: Top climate scientists are sceptical that nations will rein in global warming
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02990-wA Nature survey reveals that many authors of the latest IPCC climate-science report are anxious about the future and expect to see catastrophic changes in their lifetimes.

column1: How climate coverage can drive change
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03002-7Three case studies show how Nature articles influence climate policy.

column1: The vaccine shots that rang around the world
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02996-4Two books follow key runners in the historic race to immunize the world against COVID.

column1: Scientists say Australian plan to cull up to 10,000 wild horses doesn’t go far enough
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02977-7A fast-growing population of feral horses in an alpine national park needs to be substantially reduced in number, researchers argue.

column1: A reconstruction of early cryptic COVID spread
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02989-3To respond better to future pandemics, we must understand how the SARS-CoV-2 virus dispersed so rapidly. A model of COVID-19 spread sheds light on cryptic transmission, undetected by surveillance efforts, in early 2020.

column1: Refining the toolkit for sugar analysis
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03000-9Antibodies and other reagents for glycans have lagged behind those for proteins and nucleic acids, but the field is catching up.

column1: Virus detective: searching for Zika, dengue and SARS-CoV-2
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03001-8Danielle Bruna Leal de Oliveira tracks pathogens for Brazil’s public-health system.

column1: Scientists’ fears of racial bias surge amid US crackdown on China ties
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02976-8Poll shows that researchers of Chinese descent worry about surveillance by the US government and have stepped back from collaborations in China.

column1: Common antidepressant slashes risk of COVID death
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02988-4Fluvoxamine is both inexpensive and highly effective at preventing mild COVID-19 from turning severe.

column1: Abdul Qadeer Khan (1936–2021)
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02997-3Materials scientist behind Pakistan’s nuclear-weapons business.

column1: The search for people who never get COVID
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02978-6An international team of researchers wants to find people who are genetically resistant to SARS-CoV-2, in the hope of developing new drugs and treatments.

column1: When you recommend someone for an opportunity, follow through
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03004-5Sponsoring someone is not a one-off act. Their success is your success, so support them throughout the process.

column1: Beware of rainbows
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02961-1The sacred and profane.

column1: Daily briefing: A COVID drug for the people?
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03006-3The inexpensive antidepressant fluvoxamine cuts the risk of death among high-risk COVID-19 patients. Plus: the search for people who are genetically resistant to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and the effects of civil war on bird life.

column1: Coronapod: China's crucial COVID vaccines start to falter
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03005-4Two inactivated virus vaccines from China account for half the world's inoculations against COVID, now their protection may be waning.

column1: The faint little galaxies that could shed light on the early cosmos
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02943-3Small galaxies seem to be forming stars the old-fashioned way: in splendid isolation.

column1: Curbing fossil fuels and a look inside cells — the week in infographics
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02975-9Nature highlights three key infographics from the week in science and research.

column1: How ‘sleep misperception’ fools people into thinking they don’t sleep
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02942-4Research on slumbering volunteers reveals the surprising stage when we feel most deeply asleep.

column1: All in the mind: what the placebo effect looks like in the brain
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02939-zWhen pain relief is expected, specific circuits in the brainstem become more active.

column1: Enigmatic Falklands ‘fox’ might have hitched a ride with humans
column3: Nature, Published online: 29 October 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02946-0Findings suggest that people lived on the islands earlier than thought — and could have imported the canid called the warrah.

column1: There is no silver bullet against climate change
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02980-yThere is no silver bullet against climate change

column1: Colour blindness: journals should enable image redisplay
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02982-wColour blindness: journals should enable image redisplay

column1: Embrace open-source sensors for local climate studies
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02981-xEmbrace open-source sensors for local climate studies

column1: For NGOs, article-processing charges sap conservation funds
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02979-5For NGOs, article-processing charges sap conservation funds

column1: Tips for managing an industry move without your academic supervisor’s support
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02999-1Struggling with your principal investigator’s bias towards academia? Here are some workarounds.

column1: Scientists: don’t feed the doubt machine
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02993-7From climate to COVID, naivety about how science is hijacked promotes more of the same.

column1: Water bear fossil and grizzly bear selfie — October’s best science images
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02880-1The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.

column1: Daily briefing: A scientists’ guide to COP26
column3: Nature, Published online: 01 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03019-yAs the COP26 climate conference kicks off, Nature explains what success looks like, and what’s on the line. Plus, we explore the nuclear legacy of Abdul Qadeer Khan and learn that honey bees ‘social distance’ to fight mites.

column1: From the archive
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02952-2Nature’s pages feature efforts to ensure thermometer accuracy and offer some gardening advice.

column1: Why scientists worldwide are watching UK COVID infections
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03003-6The country’s relaxation of measures such as masking — especially in England — is showing the limits of relying on vaccines alone.

column1: All aboard the climate train! Scientists join activists for COP26 trip
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03008-1Journey to pivotal climate summit offers a glimpse into the hopes and fears of researchers travelling to the meeting.

column1: Africa accelerator, racial-bias fears and UK science budget
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02994-6The latest science news, in brief.

column1: African scientists race to test COVID drugs — but face major hurdles
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02995-5In a bid to stave off looming disaster, scientists are trying to repurpose drugs used for malaria and other diseases, but infrastructure and recruitment challenges stymie progress.

column1: Glass is the hidden gem in a carbon-neutral future
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02992-8Recycling glass does not degrade it, and manufacturing it can be carbon-free. So why are many countries still burying glass in the ground?

column1: Daily briefing: How scientists can grapple with merchants of doubt
column3: Nature, Published online: 02 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03032-1How to respond when science is hijacked to bolster false claims. Plus, the month’s best science images and the day at COP26.

column1: Eight reasons you are alone
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02963-zA way forward.

column1: The African Academy of Sciences is in crisis — responsibility must be shared
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02991-9The pan-African science academy is in turmoil. Funders and fellows must jointly own the crisis, and work to stop it happening again.

column1: Publisher Correction: An open-access volume electron microscopy atlas of whole cells and tissues
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04132-8Publisher Correction: An open-access volume electron microscopy atlas of whole cells and tissues

column1: Author Correction: Large metallicity variations in the Galactic interstellar medium
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04146-2Author Correction: Large metallicity variations in the Galactic interstellar medium

column1: Publisher Correction: A metastasis map of human cancer cell lines
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04149-zPublisher Correction: A metastasis map of human cancer cell lines

column1: Publisher Correction: Observation of fractional edge excitations in nanographene spin chains
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04150-6Publisher Correction: Observation of fractional edge excitations in nanographene spin chains

column1: Cross-HLA targeting of intracellular oncoproteins with peptide-centric CARs
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04061-6Targeting peptides from unmutated cancer drivers that are expressed in tumours but not in normal tissues using peptide-centric chimeric antigen receptors shows potential as treatment for cancer.

column1: Reconstruction of Bloch wavefunctions of holes in a semiconductor
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03940-2Bloch wavefunctions of two types of hole in gallium arsenide are reconstructed by measuring the polarization of light emitted by collisions of electrons and holes accelerated by a terahertz laser.

column1: Episodic deluges in simulated hothouse climates
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03919-zThrough an idealized set of simulations, with a model that incorporates key physics, research reveals dramatic swings between massive rainfall events and extended dry periods in hothouse climates.

column1: Disruption of mitochondrial complex I induces progressive parkinsonism
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04059-0Dysfunction of mitochondrial complex I in mice is sufficient to cause progressive parkinsonism in which the loss of nigral dopamine release critically contributes to motor dysfunction.

column1: B cell-derived GABA elicits IL-10+ macrophages to limit anti-tumour immunity
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04082-1A paper in Nature demonstrates that B cell-derived GABA promotes monocyte differentiation into anti-inflammatory macrophages able to limit anti-tumour T cell cytotoxicity.

column1: Terrestrial-type nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between seagrass and a marine bacterium
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04063-4The N2-fixing symbiont ‘Candidatus Celerinatantimonas neptuna’ lives inside the root tissue of the seagrass Posidonia oceanica, providing ammonia and amino acids to its host in exchange for sugars and enabling highly productive seagrass meadows to thrive in the nitrogen-limited Mediterranean Sea.

column1: Transition metal-catalysed molecular n-doping of organic semiconductors
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03942-0Electron doping of organic semiconductors is typically inefficient, but here a precursor molecular dopant is used to deliver higher n-doping efficiency in a much shorter doping time.

column1: Baleen whale prey consumption based on high-resolution foraging measurements
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03991-5A combination of 3D whale locations and acoustic measurements of prey density is used here to show that whales’ consumption of krill is several times larger than often thought.

column1: Few-fs resolution of a photoactive protein traversing a conical intersection
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04050-9Serial femtosecond crystallography (SFX) has provided significant understanding of time-resolved processes of various systems in biology, for example, rhodopsin, which underlies our vision. The approach involves femtosecond-length X-ray pulses directed at protein crystals and has been used to study various photoactive proteins. However, the function of proteins such as rhodopsin requires trans–cis isomerization of a chromo

column1: Carbon implications of marginal oils from market-derived demand shocks
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03932-2Here the non-linear relationship is revealed between carbon emissions reductions and oil demand reductions, which depends on the magnitude of demand drop and the global oil market structure.

column1: Cold-induced Arabidopsis FRIGIDA nuclear condensates for FLC repression
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04062-5In Arabidopsis thaliana, downregulation of the floral repressor FLC in response to cold occurs through a mechanism in which the FLC activator FRIGIDA is sequestered into biomolecular condensates away from the FLC promoter.

column1: MC3R links nutritional state to childhood growth and the timing of puberty
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04088-9MC3R deficiency is associated with a delay in the onset of puberty, and a reduction in growth and lean mass.

column1: Experimental relativistic zero-knowledge proofs
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03998-yA zero-knowledge proof, which can be used to verify secret information, is reported here with security that is enforced by the laws of special relativity.

column1: Striatal indirect pathway mediates exploration via collicular competition
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04055-4Indirect striatal projection neurons in the basal ganglia modulate activity in the superior colliculus, thereby controlling selection and exploration of actions in response to a reward omission.

column1: Percolation transitions in compressed SiO2 glasses
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03918-0Amorphous–amorphous phase transitions in silicon dioxide are shown to proceed through a sequence of percolation transitions, a process that has relevance to a range of important liquid and glassy systems.

column1: Drop-in Fuels from Sunlight and Air
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04174-yDrop-in Fuels from Sunlight and Air

column1: Podcast special: onboard the climate train to COP26
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03039-8Young people take centre stage as ‘climate train’ ferries scientists and activists to crucial UN climate conference.

column1: Dressed-up tumour cells make up a personalized cancer vaccine
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03021-4A dose of silica-coated cancer cells helps to rally the immune system against malignancies in mice.

column1: Maps reveal surprising details of Mongols’ ancient capital
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03013-4Sensors that peer underground chart the unexpected sprawl of Karakorum, established by the heir to Genghis Khan.

column1: Deadline divide: women shy away from asking for extensions
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03014-3Even when deadlines are flexible, women are less likely than men to seek extra time for assignments.

column1: ‘Flash’ droughts are quick-drying farm fields globally
column3: Nature, Published online: 03 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03009-0Important crop-growing regions, such as Brazil, are susceptible to droughts that strike with alarming speed.

column1: When are masks most useful? COVID cases offer hints
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03030-3Masks offer the greatest protection indoors and during long exposures to people infected with the coronavirus — but other public-health measures matter, too.

column1: Fifty years of the brain’s sense of space
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03010-7Neurons in a brain region called the hippocampus were found to be selectively active when rats are in a specific spatial location during natural navigation. The discovery launched research efforts into how the brain supports spatial memory.

column1: US astronomy's 10-year plan is super-ambitious
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03027-yIts ‘decadal survey’ pitches big new space observatories, funding for large telescopes and a reckoning over social issues plaguing the field.

column1: Carbon emissions see rapid rebound following COVID pandemic dip
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03036-xAs major climate summit gets under way, the latest data underscore countries’ dangerous dependence on fossil fuels.

column1: Carbon emissions rapidly rebounded following COVID pandemic dip
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03036-xAs the COP26 climate summit rolls along, the latest data underscore countries’ dangerous dependence on fossil fuels.

column1: The power of poo, and what to expect from robots: Books in brief
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03067-4Andrew Robinson reviews five of the week’s best science picks.

column1: Scientists cheer India’s ambitious carbon-zero climate pledge
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03044-xIndia’s 2070 goal could help limit global warming to 1.5 °C, say researchers — but it will require the nation to juggle steep emissions cuts with lifting a significant proportion of its population out of poverty.

column1: Whales’ gigantic appetites, climate fears — the week in infographics
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03066-5Nature highlights three key infographics from the week in science and research.

column1: My first pet
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02965-xThe needle in a haystack.

column1: Daily briefing: Whaling ripped a huge hole in the ocean’s food web
column3: Nature, Published online: 04 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03073-6How whaling devastated a once-rich undersea ecosystem — and how to restore the cycle. Plus, evidence for when masks are most useful against COVID-19, and the super-ambitious ten-year plan for US astronomy.

column1: Sponge cells hint at origins of nervous system
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03015-2Synapse genes help cells to communicate in sponge’s digestive chambers.

column1: Line in the sand: the physics of halting a dune on the march
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03023-2A laboratory ‘roundabout’ helps scientists to determine the types of barrier that can halt an underwater dune’s travels.

column1: Worker ants vault to queenly rank after just one gene turns on
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03024-1One master switch controls a wide range of behaviours in an ant that undergoes a radical makeover.

column1: Whale-cams reveal how much they really eat
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03026-zBaleen whales consume twice as much krill as previously estimated.

column1: COP26 climate pledges: What scientists think so far
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03034-zNations have promised to end deforestation, curb methane emissions and stop public investment in coal power. Researchers warn that the real work of COP26 is yet to come.

column1: Scientists glimpse little galactic clusters on their way to greatness
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03022-3Light from 11 billion years ago provides a view of galactic ‘protoclusters’ that could grow into behemoths.

column1: Are mothers too easy to blame?
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03053-wA book critiques the evidence for epigenetic inheritance of trauma.

column1: Daily briefing: Global CO2 emissions might have been flat for a decade
column3: Nature, Published online: 05 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03083-4Carbon emissions have rebounded after COVID shutdowns, but a reassessment of croplands offers hints of hope. Plus, breakthroughs and bombast from the first week of COP26.

column1: ‘I have to use a torch and watch my step’: netting seabirds at night
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03055-8Kendrew Colhoun tracks the movements of migratory birds in Ireland.

column1: How protein-based COVID vaccines could change the pandemic
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03025-0Jabs from Novavax and other biotech firms are coming. Scientists say they have a lot to offer.

column1: The COVID pandemic has harmed researcher productivity – and mental health
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03045-wSurveys show that women, parents of young children and people of colour are most affected by pandemic-related disruptions and need more support.

column1: Scammers impersonate guest editors to get sham papers published
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03035-yHundreds of junk-science papers have been retracted from reputable journals after fraudsters used ‘special issues’ to manipulate the publication process. And the problem is growing.

column1: COP26 scientist: How much carbon can the ocean absorb?
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03029-wResearchers at COP26 speak of their hopes and fears for the momentous climate summit — and what they hope to achieve by attending.

column1: Remembering a great friend of Nature
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03069-2Remembering a great friend of Nature

column1: Japan: prize diversity, not conformity, to boost research
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03070-9Japan: prize diversity, not conformity, to boost research

column1: Replication efforts have limited epistemic value
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03068-3Replication efforts have limited epistemic value

column1: An expanding molecular toolbox untangles neural circuits
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03054-9Scientists are developing ways to probe the activity, function and organization of neurons in real time with increasing precision.

column1: Daily briefing: Pfizer’s COVID pill looks promising
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03379-5Pfizer antiviral cut the risk of hospitalization or death by 89% for vulnerable people newly diagnosed with COVID-19. Plus, what sponges can tell us about the nervous system, and scientists judge the COP pledges so far.

column1: Audio long-read: How dangerous is Africa’s explosive Lake Kivu?
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02984-8A lake in central Africa could one day release a huge amount of greenhouse gases, threatening the lives of millions.

column1: Astrophysicists unveil glut of gravitational-wave detections
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03089-yThe latest bounty of 35 events features oddball black holes and a miniature neutron star.

column1: Simplify drug labelling to show benefits clearly
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03050-zRegulators and researchers should give patients and physicians meaningful information to guide decisions.

column1: COP26 scientist: Humanitarian aid must prepare for climate emergency
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03029-wResearchers at COP26 speak of their hopes and fears for the momentous climate summit — and what they hope to achieve by attending.

column1: Temporal controls over inter-areal cortical projection neuron fate diversity
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04048-3Combined analysis of the connectome and transcriptome in the mouse cortex indicates that dynamic differences in expression levels of largely generic sets of genes regulate differential targeting within neuronal subtypes.

column1: Your COP26 questions answered: carbon capture and storage
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03391-9What is the most promising carbon capture tech and is it safe?

column1: ‘Brumby’ cull, carbon rebound and a giant research index
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03051-yThe latest science news, in brief.

column1: COP architects furious at lack of climate justice at pivotal summit
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03088-zScientists who worked on the original UN climate convention doubt that COP26 will deliver for low income countries.

column1: Scientists count the career costs of COVID
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03040-1As the pandemic continues, researchers are coming to terms with what they’ve learnt and lost so far, finds Nature’s global survey.

column1: COVID is disrupting scientific careers around the world
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03049-6Earlier generations faced fallout from the global financial crisis and a boost from emerging economies. Today, COVID-19 and concerns about diversity dominate.

column1: Bendable mini-scanner records every loop of a fingerprint
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03075-4A device that can fit in a person’s palm has enough resolution to capture fingerprints for biometric identification.

column1: Daily briefing: What happened when one lab gave its reagents away
column3: Nature, Published online: 09 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03387-5“We dared to ask: what if we just give everything away?” Plus, scammers impersonate guest editors to get sham papers published, and the world’s climate pledges might be built on flawed data.

column1: Pandemic’s plastic waste is choking the seas
column3: Nature, Published online: 08 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03078-1The onslaught of COVID-19 has generated millions of tonnes of plastic waste in the form of gloves, face masks and other items.

column1: Goldbergian physics
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-02967-9Keeping things neat and tidy.

column1: Weird crystal makes beetle a living jewel
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03076-3An insect owes its bright green covering to an unusual type of ‘photonic crystal’.

column1: How to get a job in vaccine development
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03057-6Robin Shattock advises researchers to follow their scientific instincts, and be flexible and resilient.

column1: A guide on how to work in vaccine science
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03056-7Researchers describe what it takes to succeed in a high-profile field at an extraordinary time.

column1: Temporal transitions in the post-mitotic nervous system of Caenorhabditis elegans
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04071-4In the post-mitotic nervous system of Caenorhabditis elegans, the promotion of a mature neuronal transcription program is controlled by the developmental-stage-specific upregulation of the microRNA LIN-4 and the subsequent repression of its target, the transcription factor lin-14.

column1: Host immunomodulatory lipids created by symbionts from dietary amino acids
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04083-0The symbiotic gut bacterium Bacteroides fragilis produces unique α-galactosylceramides from host dietary branched-chain amino acids, which are presented as CD1d ligands and immunomodulate natural killer T cells.

column1: Self-guarding of MORC3 enables virulence factor-triggered immunity
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04054-5MORC3 is revealed as an essential negative regulator of the anti-viral interferon response that functions in an innate immune pathway that detects viral virulence factors.

column1: Target site selection and remodelling by type V CRISPR-transposon systems
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04030-zStructural studies on Scytonema hofmanni CRISPR-associated transposon protein complexes indicate a mechanism for RNA-guided DNA transposition involving Cas12k, TnsC and TnsB.

column1: An optical lattice with sound
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03945-xAn optical lattice for trapping a Bose–Einstein condensate reported here includes photon-mediated atom–atom interactions that replicate acoustic modes in real crystals.

column1: A chickpea genetic variation map based on the sequencing of 3,366 genomes
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04066-1Whole-genome sequencing of 3,171 cultivated and 195 wild chickpea accessions is used to construct a chickpea pan-genome, providing insight into chickpea evolution and enabling breeding strategies that could improve crop productivity.

column1: Triangulation supports agricultural spread of the Transeurasian languages
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04108-8A ‘triangulation’ approach combining linguistics, archaeology and genetics suggests that the origin and spread of Transeurasian family of languages can be traced back to early millet farmers in Neolithic North East Asia.

column1: Cognitive control persistently enhances hippocampal information processing
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04070-5Studies in mice show that cognitive control training rapidly improves brain circuit function and enhances subsequent learning, which both persist for months.

column1: Dietary palmitic acid promotes a prometastatic memory via Schwann cells
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04075-0Palmitic acid induces stable transcriptional and chromatin changes that lead to long-term stimulation of metastasis in orthotopic models of cancer through the secretion by tumour-associated Schwann cells of a specialized proregenerative extracellular matrix, the ablation of which inhibits metastasis initiation.

column1: Structures of the HER2–HER3–NRG1β complex reveal a dynamic dimer interface
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04084-zCryo-electron microscopy structures of the HER2–HER3–NRG1β complex reveal a dynamic HER2–HER3 interface and explain the mechanism for the activating HER2 cancer mutations.

column1: In situ formation of ZnOx species for efficient propane dehydrogenation
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03923-3Propene is obtained through propane dehydrogenation using catalysts that are toxic, expensive or demanding to regenerate with ecologically harmful compounds, but the ZnO-based alternative reported here is cheap, clean and scalable.

column1: Allometric rules for mammalian cortical layer 5 neuron biophysics
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04072-3Analyses of layer 5 cortical pyramidal neurons in 10 mammalian species show that human neurons are distinct in that they do not follow the expected allometric relationship between neuron size and membrane conductance.

column1: Diverse alterations associated with resistance to KRAS(G12C) inhibition
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04065-2Multiple treatment-emergent alterations appear in patients with advanced-stage cancer who were treated with a KRAS inhibitor.

column1: Globally resolved surface temperatures since the Last Glacial Maximum
column3: Nature, Published online: 10 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03984-4Paleoclimate datasets are integrated with a climate model to reconstruct global surface temperature since the Last Glacial Maximum, showing sustained warming until the mid-Holocene.

column1: Single-cell transcriptomic characterization of a gastrulating human embryo
column3: Nature, Published online: 17 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-04158-yThe single-cell transcriptional profile of a human embryo between 16 and 19 days after fertilization reveals parallels and differences in gastrulation in humans as compared with mouse and non-human primate models.

column1: Observation of Stark many-body localization without disorder
column3: Nature, Published online: 17 November 2021; doi:10.1038/s41586-021-03988-0Experiments with a trapped-ion quantum simulator observe Stark many-body localization, in which the quantum system evades thermalization despite having no disorder.

column1: Cortical responses to touch reflect subcortical integration of LTMR signals

column1: Structure, function and pharmacology of human itch receptor complexes

column1: Approaching the intrinsic exciton physics limit in two-dimensional semiconductor diodes

column1: Europe’s COVID death toll could rise by hundreds of thousands

column3: Nature, Published online: 18 November 2021; doi:10.1038/d41586-021-03482-7Our quest to bring a child into our family led us to confront academic working practices, say Tony Ly and Nathan W. Bailey.
